trans-unit.source: BizTalk Rules
trans-unit.target: BizTalk Rules

trans-unit.source: This topic covers the features of BizTalk Rules and provides instructions on its usage
trans-unit.target: This topic covers the features of BizTalk Rules and provides instructions on its usage

trans-unit.source: Business Rules encapsulates the policies and decisions that control business processes.
trans-unit.target: Business Rules encapsulates the policies and decisions that control business processes.

trans-unit.source: These policies may be formally defined in procedure manuals, contracts, or agreements, or may exist as knowledge or expertise embodied in employees.
trans-unit.target: These policies may be formally defined in procedure manuals, contracts, or agreements, or may exist as knowledge or expertise embodied in employees.

trans-unit.source: These policies are dynamic and subject to change over time due to changes in business plans, regulations or other reasons.
trans-unit.target: These policies are dynamic and subject to change over time due to changes in business plans, regulations or other reasons.

trans-unit.source: Implementing these policies in traditional programming languages requires substantial time and coordination, and does not enable non-programmers to participate in creation and maintenance of business policies.
trans-unit.target: Implementing these policies in traditional programming languages requires substantial time and coordination, and does not enable non-programmers to participate in creation and maintenance of business policies.

trans-unit.source: BizTalk Business Rules provides a way to rapidly implement these policies and decouple the rest of the business process.
trans-unit.target: BizTalk Business Rules provides a way to rapidly implement these policies and decouple the rest of the business process.

trans-unit.source: This allows for making required changes to business policies without impacting the rest of the business process.
trans-unit.target: This allows for making required changes to business policies without impacting the rest of the business process.

trans-unit.source: There are 3 key reasons to use BizTalk Business Rules in business process:
trans-unit.target: There are 3 key reasons to use BizTalk Business Rules in business process:

trans-unit.source: Decouple Business logic from Application code
trans-unit.target: Decouple Business logic from Application code

trans-unit.source: Allow Business Analysts to have more control over business logic management
trans-unit.target: Allow Business Analysts to have more control over business logic management

trans-unit.source: Changes to business logic go to production faster
trans-unit.target: Changes to business logic go to production faster

trans-unit.source: The terms used to define rule conditions and actions are usually expressed by domain or industry-specific nomenclature.
trans-unit.target: The terms used to define rule conditions and actions are usually expressed by domain or industry-specific nomenclature.

trans-unit.source: For example, an e-mail user writes rules in terms of messages "received from" and messages "received after," while an insurance business analyst writes rules in terms of "risk factors" and "coverage amount."
trans-unit.target: For example, an e-mail user writes rules in terms of messages "received from" and messages "received after," while an insurance business analyst writes rules in terms of "risk factors" and "coverage amount."

trans-unit.source: Underlying this domain-specific terminology are the technology artifacts (objects, database tables, and XML documents) that implement rule conditions and rule actions.
trans-unit.target: Underlying this domain-specific terminology are the technology artifacts (objects, database tables, and XML documents) that implement rule conditions and rule actions.

trans-unit.source: Vocabularies are designed to bridge the gap between business semantics and implementation.
trans-unit.target: Vocabularies are designed to bridge the gap between business semantics and implementation.

trans-unit.source: For example, a data binding for an approval status might point to a certain column in a certain row in a certain database, represented as an SQL query.
trans-unit.target: For example, a data binding for an approval status might point to a certain column in a certain row in a certain database, represented as an SQL query.

trans-unit.source: Instead of inserting this sort of complex representation in a rule, you might instead create a vocabulary definition, associated with that data binding, with a friendly name of "Status."
trans-unit.target: Instead of inserting this sort of complex representation in a rule, you might instead create a vocabulary definition, associated with that data binding, with a friendly name of "Status."

trans-unit.source: Subsequently you can include "Status" in any number of rules, and the rule engine can retrieve the corresponding data from the table.
trans-unit.target: Subsequently you can include "Status" in any number of rules, and the rule engine can retrieve the corresponding data from the table.

trans-unit.source: A vocabulary is a collection of definitions consisting of friendly names for the computing objects used in rule conditions and actions.
trans-unit.target: A vocabulary is a collection of definitions consisting of friendly names for the computing objects used in rule conditions and actions.

trans-unit.source: Vocabulary definitions make the rules easier to read, understand, and share by people in a particular business domain.
trans-unit.target: Vocabulary definitions make the rules easier to read, understand, and share by people in a particular business domain.

trans-unit.source: Business rules are declarative statements that govern the conduct of business processes.
trans-unit.target: Business rules are declarative statements that govern the conduct of business processes.

trans-unit.source: A rule consists of a condition and actions.
trans-unit.target: A rule consists of a condition and actions.

trans-unit.source: The condition is evaluated, and if it evaluates to true, the rule engine initiates one or more actions.
trans-unit.target: The condition is evaluated, and if it evaluates to true, the rule engine initiates one or more actions.

trans-unit.source: Rules in the Business Rules Framework are defined by using the following format:
trans-unit.target: Rules in the Business Rules Framework are defined by using the following format:

trans-unit.source: IF condition THEN action
trans-unit.target: IF condition THEN action

trans-unit.source: Consider the following example:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following example:

trans-unit.source: IF amount is less than or equal to available funds THEN conduct transaction and print receipt
trans-unit.target: IF amount is less than or equal to available funds THEN conduct transaction and print receipt

trans-unit.source: This rule determines whether a transaction will be conducted by applying business logic, in the form of a comparison of two monetary values, in the form of a transaction amount and available funds.
trans-unit.target: This rule determines whether a transaction will be conducted by applying business logic, in the form of a comparison of two monetary values, in the form of a transaction amount and available funds.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Business Rule to create, modify, and deploy business rules.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Business Rule to create, modify, and deploy business rules.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can perform the preceding tasks programmatically.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can perform the preceding tasks programmatically.

trans-unit.source: A condition is a true/false (Boolean) expression that consists of one or more predicates.
trans-unit.target: A condition is a true/false (Boolean) expression that consists of one or more predicates.

trans-unit.source: In our example, the predicate less than or equal to is applied to the amount and available funds.
trans-unit.target: In our example, the predicate less than or equal to is applied to the amount and available funds.

trans-unit.source: This condition will always evaluate to either true or false.
trans-unit.target: This condition will always evaluate to either true or false.

trans-unit.source: Predicates can be combined with the logical operators AND, OR, and NOT to form a logical expression that is potentially quite large, but will always evaluate to either true or false.
trans-unit.target: Predicates can be combined with the logical operators AND, OR, and NOT to form a logical expression that is potentially quite large, but will always evaluate to either true or false.

trans-unit.source: Actions are the functional consequences of condition evaluation.
trans-unit.target: Actions are the functional consequences of condition evaluation.

trans-unit.source: If a rule condition is met, a corresponding action or actions are initiated.
trans-unit.target: If a rule condition is met, a corresponding action or actions are initiated.

trans-unit.source: In our example, "conduct transaction" and "print receipt" are actions that are carried out when, and only when, the condition (in this case, "IF amount is less than or equal to available funds") is true.
trans-unit.target: In our example, "conduct transaction" and "print receipt" are actions that are carried out when, and only when, the condition (in this case, "IF amount is less than or equal to available funds") is true.

trans-unit.source: Actions are represented in the Business Rules Framework by performing set operations on XML documents.
trans-unit.target: Actions are represented in the Business Rules Framework by performing set operations on XML documents.

trans-unit.source: A policy is a logical grouping of rules.
trans-unit.target: A policy is a logical grouping of rules.

trans-unit.source: You compose a policy, save it, test it and, when you are satisfied with the results, use it in a production environment.
trans-unit.target: You compose a policy, save it, test it and, when you are satisfied with the results, use it in a production environment.

trans-unit.source: You can compose policies in the Rules portal.
trans-unit.target: You can compose policies in the Rules portal.

trans-unit.source: A policy can contain an arbitrarily large set of rules, but typically you compose a policy from rules that pertain to a specific business domain within the context of the application that will be using the policy.
trans-unit.target: A policy can contain an arbitrarily large set of rules, but typically you compose a policy from rules that pertain to a specific business domain within the context of the application that will be using the policy.

trans-unit.source: You can effectively perform a test run of your policy before it is used in a production environment.
trans-unit.target: You can effectively perform a test run of your policy before it is used in a production environment.

trans-unit.source: The Rules Portal allows you to supply inputs to a policy, run the policy, and view its output.
trans-unit.target: The Rules Portal allows you to supply inputs to a policy, run the policy, and view its output.

trans-unit.source: The output includes logs, rule execution, condition evaluation, and resulting outputs.
trans-unit.target: The output includes logs, rule execution, condition evaluation, and resulting outputs.

trans-unit.source: Let’s take a sample scenario and walk through it as we compose the Business Logic for the same.
trans-unit.target: Let’s take a sample scenario and walk through it as we compose the Business Logic for the same.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In a really simple Insurance Claims scenario, the Claimant submits his insurance claim (via any client like website, phone App, etc).
trans-unit.target: In a really simple Insurance Claims scenario, the Claimant submits his insurance claim (via any client like website, phone App, etc).

trans-unit.source: This Claim Request gets sent to the business’s Claim Processing Unit and based on the result of the processing, the Claim can be either Approved, Rejected or sent along for further manual processing.
trans-unit.target: This Claim Request gets sent to the business’s Claim Processing Unit and based on the result of the processing, the Claim can be either Approved, Rejected or sent along for further manual processing.

trans-unit.source: The Claim Processing Unit in our scenario would be the one encompassing the Business logic for the system.
trans-unit.target: The Claim Processing Unit in our scenario would be the one encompassing the Business logic for the system.

trans-unit.source: Taking a closer look at this unit, we can see the following:
trans-unit.target: Taking a closer look at this unit, we can see the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Let us now use Business Rules to implement this business logic.
trans-unit.target: Let us now use Business Rules to implement this business logic.

trans-unit.source: Login to the Azure Portal and get to the home page.
trans-unit.target: Login to the Azure Portal and get to the home page.

trans-unit.source: Click on New->Azure Marketplace->API Apps->Biz Talk Rules->Create <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click on New->Azure Marketplace->API Apps->Biz Talk Rules->Create <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the new blade that opens, enter the following information:
trans-unit.target: In the new blade that opens, enter the following information:

trans-unit.source: Name – give a name for your Rules API App
trans-unit.target: Name – give a name for your Rules API App

trans-unit.source: App Hosting Plan – select or create a web hosting plan
trans-unit.target: App Hosting Plan – select or create a web hosting plan

trans-unit.source: Pricing Tier – Choose the pricing tier you want this App to reside in
trans-unit.target: Pricing Tier – Choose the pricing tier you want this App to reside in

trans-unit.source: Resource Group – Select or create Resource group where the App should reside in
trans-unit.target: Resource Group – Select or create Resource group where the App should reside in

trans-unit.source: Location – Choose the geographic location where you would like the App to be deployed.
trans-unit.target: Location – Choose the geographic location where you would like the App to be deployed.

trans-unit.source: Click on Create.
trans-unit.target: Click on Create.

trans-unit.source: Within a few minutes your BizTalk Rules API App would be created.
trans-unit.target: Within a few minutes your BizTalk Rules API App would be created.

trans-unit.source: After creating a BizTalk Rules API App, the next step would be to create vocabularies.
trans-unit.target: After creating a BizTalk Rules API App, the next step would be to create vocabularies.

trans-unit.source: The expectation is that the developer is the more common persona to be doing this exercise.
trans-unit.target: The expectation is that the developer is the more common persona to be doing this exercise.

trans-unit.source: To do this follow the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To do this follow the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Browse to the created API App by Browse->API Apps-><Your Rules API App>. This should get you to the Rules API App Dashboard similar to below:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the created API App by Browse->API Apps-><Your Rules API App>. This should get you to the Rules API App Dashboard similar to below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: 2.Next Click on “Vocabulary definitions”.
trans-unit.target: 2.Next Click on “Vocabulary definitions”.

trans-unit.source: This would show you the Vocabulary Authoring Screen.
trans-unit.target: This would show you the Vocabulary Authoring Screen.

trans-unit.source: Click on “Add” to begin adding new vocabulary definitions.
trans-unit.target: Click on “Add” to begin adding new vocabulary definitions.

trans-unit.source: There are 2 types of vocabulary definitions currently supported – Literal and XML.
trans-unit.target: There are 2 types of vocabulary definitions currently supported – Literal and XML.

trans-unit.source: After clicking on “Add”, a new “Add Definition” Blade Opens up.
trans-unit.target: After clicking on “Add”, a new “Add Definition” Blade Opens up.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following values
trans-unit.target: Enter the following values

trans-unit.source: Name – only alphanumeric characters are expected without any special characters.
trans-unit.target: Name – only alphanumeric characters are expected without any special characters.

trans-unit.source: This should also be unique to your existing vocabulary definition list.
trans-unit.target: This should also be unique to your existing vocabulary definition list.

trans-unit.source: Description – optional field.
trans-unit.target: Description – optional field.

trans-unit.source: Type – there are 2 types supported.
trans-unit.target: Type – there are 2 types supported.

trans-unit.source: Choose Literal in this example
trans-unit.target: Choose Literal in this example

trans-unit.source: Input type – this allows users to select the data type of the definition.
trans-unit.target: Input type – this allows users to select the data type of the definition.

trans-unit.source: Currently 4 data types are selectable: i.
trans-unit.target: Currently 4 data types are selectable: i.

trans-unit.source: String – these values must be entered in double quotes (“Example String”) ii.
trans-unit.target: String – these values must be entered in double quotes (“Example String”) ii.

trans-unit.source: Boolean – this can either be true or false iii.
trans-unit.target: Boolean – this can either be true or false iii.

trans-unit.source: Number – can be any decimal number iv.
trans-unit.target: Number – can be any decimal number iv.

trans-unit.source: DateTime – this means that the def is of type date type.
trans-unit.target: DateTime – this means that the def is of type date type.

trans-unit.source: Data must be entered using this format – mm/dd/yyyy hh:mm:ss AM\PM v. Input – This is where you enter the value of your definition.
trans-unit.target: Data must be entered using this format – mm/dd/yyyy hh:mm:ss AM\PM v. Input – This is where you enter the value of your definition.

trans-unit.source: The values entered here must conform to the chosen data type.
trans-unit.target: The values entered here must conform to the chosen data type.

trans-unit.source: User can either enter a single value, a set of values separated by commas, or a range of values using keyword to.
trans-unit.target: User can either enter a single value, a set of values separated by commas, or a range of values using keyword to.

trans-unit.source: For eg., user can enter unique value 1; a set 1, 2, 3; or a range 1 to 5.
trans-unit.target: For eg., user can enter unique value 1; a set 1, 2, 3; or a range 1 to 5.

trans-unit.source: Note that range is only supported for number.
trans-unit.target: Note that range is only supported for number.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If Vocabulary Type is chosen as XML, the following inputs needs to be specified a.
trans-unit.target: If Vocabulary Type is chosen as XML, the following inputs needs to be specified a.

trans-unit.source: Schema – Clicking on this will open a new blade allowing user to either choose from a list of already uploaded schemas or allowing to upload a new one.
trans-unit.target: Schema – Clicking on this will open a new blade allowing user to either choose from a list of already uploaded schemas or allowing to upload a new one.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: XPATH – this input gets unlocked only after choosing a schema in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: XPATH – this input gets unlocked only after choosing a schema in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on this will display the schema that was selected and allows the user to select the node for which a vocabulary definition needs to be created.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on this will display the schema that was selected and allows the user to select the node for which a vocabulary definition needs to be created.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: FACT – This input identifies which data object would be fed to the rules engine for processing.
trans-unit.target: FACT – This input identifies which data object would be fed to the rules engine for processing.

trans-unit.source: This is an advanced property and by default is set to the parent of the selected XPATH.
trans-unit.target: This is an advanced property and by default is set to the parent of the selected XPATH.

trans-unit.source: FACT becomes particularly important for chaining and collection scenarios.
trans-unit.target: FACT becomes particularly important for chaining and collection scenarios.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The above steps have captured the experience for creating Vocabulary definitions.
trans-unit.target: The above steps have captured the experience for creating Vocabulary definitions.

trans-unit.source: Once created, the created vocabulary definitions will appear in list form.
trans-unit.target: Once created, the created vocabulary definitions will appear in list form.

trans-unit.source: There are requirements to be able to generate multiple definitions from the same schema instead of repeating the above steps every single time.
trans-unit.target: There are requirements to be able to generate multiple definitions from the same schema instead of repeating the above steps every single time.

trans-unit.source: This is where Add Bulk capability becomes very useful.
trans-unit.target: This is where Add Bulk capability becomes very useful.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on “Add Bulk” will take you to a new blade.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on “Add Bulk” will take you to a new blade.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to select the schema for which multiple definitions are to be created.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to select the schema for which multiple definitions are to be created.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on this will open a new blade allowing user to either choose from a list of already uploaded schemas or allowing to upload a new one.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on this will open a new blade allowing user to either choose from a list of already uploaded schemas or allowing to upload a new one.

trans-unit.source: Now the XPATHS property gets unlocked.
trans-unit.target: Now the XPATHS property gets unlocked.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on this will open the Schema Viewer where multiple nodes can be selected.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on this will open the Schema Viewer where multiple nodes can be selected.

trans-unit.source: The names for the multiple definitions created will default to the name of the node selected.
trans-unit.target: The names for the multiple definitions created will default to the name of the node selected.

trans-unit.source: These can always be modified after creation.
trans-unit.target: These can always be modified after creation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the developer has created required vocabularies, the expectation is that the Business Analyst would be the one creating Business Policies via the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Once the developer has created required vocabularies, the expectation is that the Business Analyst would be the one creating Business Policies via the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Rules App created, there is a Policy lens clicking which the user will go into the Policy creation page.
trans-unit.target: On the Rules App created, there is a Policy lens clicking which the user will go into the Policy creation page.

trans-unit.source: This page will show the list of policies, this particular Rules App has.
trans-unit.target: This page will show the list of policies, this particular Rules App has.

trans-unit.source: User can add a new Policy by simply typing a policy name and hitting tab.
trans-unit.target: User can add a new Policy by simply typing a policy name and hitting tab.

trans-unit.source: Multiple policies can reside in a single Rules API App.
trans-unit.target: Multiple policies can reside in a single Rules API App.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on the created Policy will take the user to the Policy details page where one can see the rules that are in the policy.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on the created Policy will take the user to the Policy details page where one can see the rules that are in the policy.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText> 4.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText> 4.

trans-unit.source: Click on “Add New” to add a new rule.
trans-unit.target: Click on “Add New” to add a new rule.

trans-unit.source: This will take you to a new blade.
trans-unit.target: This will take you to a new blade.

trans-unit.source: A rule is collection of condition and action statements.
trans-unit.target: A rule is collection of condition and action statements.

trans-unit.source: The actions get executed if the condition evaluates to true.
trans-unit.target: The actions get executed if the condition evaluates to true.

trans-unit.source: In the Create Rule blade, give a unique rule name (for that policy) and description (optional).
trans-unit.target: In the Create Rule blade, give a unique rule name (for that policy) and description (optional).

trans-unit.source: The Condition box can be used to create complex conditional statements.
trans-unit.target: The Condition box can be used to create complex conditional statements.

trans-unit.source: Following are the keywords supported:
trans-unit.target: Following are the keywords supported:

trans-unit.source: And – conditional operator
trans-unit.target: And – conditional operator

trans-unit.source: Or – conditional operator
trans-unit.target: Or – conditional operator

trans-unit.source: does\not\exist
trans-unit.target: does\not\exist

trans-unit.source: exists
trans-unit.target: exists

trans-unit.source: false
trans-unit.target: false

trans-unit.source: is\equal\to
trans-unit.target: is\equal\to

trans-unit.source: is\greater\than
trans-unit.target: is\greater\than

trans-unit.source: is\greater\than\equal\to
trans-unit.target: is\greater\than\equal\to

trans-unit.source: is\_in
trans-unit.target: is\_in

trans-unit.source: is\less\than
trans-unit.target: is\less\than

trans-unit.source: is\less\than\equal\to
trans-unit.target: is\less\than\equal\to

trans-unit.source: is\not\in
trans-unit.target: is\not\in

trans-unit.source: is\not\equal\_to
trans-unit.target: is\not\equal\_to

trans-unit.source: mod
trans-unit.target: mod

trans-unit.source: true
trans-unit.target: true

trans-unit.source: The Action(Then) box can contain multiple statements, one per line, to create actions that are to be executed.
trans-unit.target: The Action(Then) box can contain multiple statements, one per line, to create actions that are to be executed.

trans-unit.source: Following are the keywords supported:
trans-unit.target: Following are the keywords supported:

trans-unit.source: equals
trans-unit.target: equals

trans-unit.source: false
trans-unit.target: false

trans-unit.source: true
trans-unit.target: true

trans-unit.source: halt
trans-unit.target: halt

trans-unit.source: mod
trans-unit.target: mod

trans-unit.source: null
trans-unit.target: null

trans-unit.source: update
trans-unit.target: update

trans-unit.source: Condition and action boxes provide Intellisense to help user author a rule quickly.
trans-unit.target: Condition and action boxes provide Intellisense to help user author a rule quickly.

trans-unit.source: This can be triggered by hitting ctrl+space or by just starting to type.
trans-unit.target: This can be triggered by hitting ctrl+space or by just starting to type.

trans-unit.source: Keywords matching typed characters will automatically be filtered down and shown.
trans-unit.target: Keywords matching typed characters will automatically be filtered down and shown.

trans-unit.source: The intellisense window will show all keywords and vocabulary definitions.
trans-unit.target: The intellisense window will show all keywords and vocabulary definitions.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: BizTalk Rules supports explicit forward chaining.
trans-unit.target: BizTalk Rules supports explicit forward chaining.

trans-unit.source: What this means is that if users would like to re-evaluate rules in response to certain actions, they can trigger this by using certain keywords.
trans-unit.target: What this means is that if users would like to re-evaluate rules in response to certain actions, they can trigger this by using certain keywords.

trans-unit.source: The following are the keywords supported:
trans-unit.target: The following are the keywords supported:

trans-unit.source: update <vocabulary definition> – this keyword re-evaluates all rules that use the specified vocabulary definition in its condition.
trans-unit.target: update <vocabulary definition> – this keyword re-evaluates all rules that use the specified vocabulary definition in its condition.

trans-unit.source: Halt – this keyword stops all rule executions
trans-unit.target: Halt – this keyword stops all rule executions

trans-unit.source: Each rule in the policy can be enabled or disabled.
trans-unit.target: Each rule in the policy can be enabled or disabled.

trans-unit.source: By default all rules are enabled.
trans-unit.target: By default all rules are enabled.

trans-unit.source: Disabled rules wont be executed during policy execution.
trans-unit.target: Disabled rules wont be executed during policy execution.

trans-unit.source: Enable\Disable rules can be done either from the rule blade directly – the commands are available in the command bar at the top of the blade, or from the policy, the context menu (right-click on a rule) has the option to enable\disable.
trans-unit.target: Enable\Disable rules can be done either from the rule blade directly – the commands are available in the command bar at the top of the blade, or from the policy, the context menu (right-click on a rule) has the option to enable\disable.

trans-unit.source: All the rules of a policy are executed in order.
trans-unit.target: All the rules of a policy are executed in order.

trans-unit.source: The priority of execution is determined by the order in which they occur in the policy.
trans-unit.target: The priority of execution is determined by the order in which they occur in the policy.

trans-unit.source: This priority can be changed by simply dragging and dropping the rule.
trans-unit.target: This priority can be changed by simply dragging and dropping the rule.

trans-unit.source: After authoring your policy, before using it in production, there is provision for testing the policy.
trans-unit.target: After authoring your policy, before using it in production, there is provision for testing the policy.

trans-unit.source: By using the “Test Policy” command, users can get into the Test Policy blade.
trans-unit.target: By using the “Test Policy” command, users can get into the Test Policy blade.

trans-unit.source: In this blade you can see a list of vocabulary definitions that are used in the policy that require a user input.
trans-unit.target: In this blade you can see a list of vocabulary definitions that are used in the policy that require a user input.

trans-unit.source: Users can manually add values for these inputs for their test scenario.
trans-unit.target: Users can manually add values for these inputs for their test scenario.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, users can also choose to import test XMLs for inputs.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, users can also choose to import test XMLs for inputs.

trans-unit.source: Once all the inputs are in, the test can be run and the outputs for each vocabulary definition will be displayed in the output column for easy comparison.
trans-unit.target: Once all the inputs are in, the test can be run and the outputs for each vocabulary definition will be displayed in the output column for easy comparison.

trans-unit.source: To view Business Analyst friendly logs, click on “View Logs” to view the execution logs.
trans-unit.target: To view Business Analyst friendly logs, click on “View Logs” to view the execution logs.

trans-unit.source: To save the logs, the “Save Output” option is available to store all test related data for independent analysis.
trans-unit.target: To save the logs, the “Save Output” option is available to store all test related data for independent analysis.

trans-unit.source: Once the policy has been authored and tested, it is now ready for consumption.
trans-unit.target: Once the policy has been authored and tested, it is now ready for consumption.

trans-unit.source: Users can create a new Logic App by doing New->Logic App.
trans-unit.target: Users can create a new Logic App by doing New->Logic App.

trans-unit.source: In the designer, BizTalk Rules is available in the gallery to the right.
trans-unit.target: In the designer, BizTalk Rules is available in the gallery to the right.

trans-unit.source: This can now be dragged and dropped onto the designer surface.
trans-unit.target: This can now be dragged and dropped onto the designer surface.

trans-unit.source: Once this is done, there will be an option to choose which Rules API App(Action) to target.
trans-unit.target: Once this is done, there will be an option to choose which Rules API App(Action) to target.

trans-unit.source: Actions include the list of policies that are to be executed.
trans-unit.target: Actions include the list of policies that are to be executed.

trans-unit.source: Choose a specific policy after which the inputs required for the policy needs to be input.
trans-unit.target: Choose a specific policy after which the inputs required for the policy needs to be input.

trans-unit.source: Users can use the output from the Rules API App downstream for further decision making.
trans-unit.target: Users can use the output from the Rules API App downstream for further decision making.

trans-unit.source: The Rules API App can also be invoked using a rich set of APIs available.
trans-unit.target: The Rules API App can also be invoked using a rich set of APIs available.

trans-unit.source: This way users aren’t restricted to just using flows and can use Rules in any application by making REST calls.
trans-unit.target: This way users aren’t restricted to just using flows and can use Rules in any application by making REST calls.

trans-unit.source: The exact REST APIs available can be viewed by clicking on the "API Definiton" lens in the Rules dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The exact REST APIs available can be viewed by clicking on the "API Definiton" lens in the Rules dashboard.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Following is an example of how one might use this API in C#
trans-unit.target: Following is an example of how one might use this API in C#

trans-unit.source: Note that the above Rules API App has its security settings set to "Public Anon".
trans-unit.target: Note that the above Rules API App has its security settings set to "Public Anon".

trans-unit.source: This can be set from within the API App using - All settings->Application Settings -> Access Level
trans-unit.target: This can be set from within the API App using - All settings->Application Settings -> Access Level

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Alt text</linkText>

trans-unit.source: One of the main advantages of using Business Rules is that changes to business logic can be pushed out to production a lot faster.
trans-unit.target: One of the main advantages of using Business Rules is that changes to business logic can be pushed out to production a lot faster.

trans-unit.source: Any change made to vocabulary and policies is immediately applied in production.
trans-unit.target: Any change made to vocabulary and policies is immediately applied in production.

trans-unit.source: User simply needs to browse to the respective vocabulary definition or policy and make the change to have it come into effect.
trans-unit.target: User simply needs to browse to the respective vocabulary definition or policy and make the change to have it come into effect.
